title: Erdos Problem #436: Consecutive kth Power Residues

problemStatement.formal: \Lambda(k,m) = \limsup_{p \to \infty} r(k,m,p) \text{ where } r(k,m,p) = \min\{r: r,\ldots,r+m-1 \text{ are } k\text{th power residues mod } p\}
problemStatement.plain: For prime p and k,m >= 2, study the minimal r such that r,...,r+m-1 are all kth power residues mod p. Key questions: Is Lambda(k,2) finite? Is Lambda(k,3) finite for odd k?
whyMatters: Deep connections between power residues and consecutive integers
Partially solved: Lambda(k,2) finite by Hildebrand (1991)
Lambda(k,3) for odd k >= 5 remains OPEN

proven: Hildebrand (1991): Lambda(k,2) finite for all k >= 2
Lehmer-Lehmer: Lambda(k,3) = infinity for even k
open: Is Lambda(k,3) finite for odd k >= 5?
Growth rate of Lambda(k,2) as function of k
